page.title: 04LANGCLIFFE: MISCELLANY
page.content: Langcliffe is a small village near to the town of Settle in the Yorkshire Dales. The village looks old, but there is evidence that there was an even earlier Langliffe which was burned by the Scots. The present village was apparently built further up the valley. Cotton mills once provided work for the people of Langcliffe, but when these fell into disuse in the middle of the 19th century, Langcliffe became for a short time like a deserted village. The mills became paper mills, and provided employment once more. In the centre of the village is a tree, called 'The Tree' by local people, under which they have talked, argued and debated for many years. It is also used on Mischief Night (called 'Flitting Night' here,) as a place where children 'flit' every moveable object.
